caseNameFull: Bonnie S. Thaler v. Mark Thaler

opinions.snippet:
Bertram Harnett, J.
Like habits, old attitudes die hard. In few parts of society’s spectrum is this as evident as it is in the relationship between the sexes. While constitutional commands may force changes in overt conduct, they do not readily alter the ingrained feelings born of a lifetime’s experience. Too, there is a subtle conceptual reciprocation at work, since many constitutional decisions bear the indeterminate weight of

attorney: William H. Sleeper (by brief and orally), for the plaintiff., James M. Jackson (by brief and orally), for the defendant Phipps., Hughes & Burns, for the defendant Kretsepis, filed no brief.
caseNameFull: Sadie Webber v. Clare H. Phipps & A.

opinions.snippet: From the evidence, the following facts could be found. The plaintiff was injured at Dover on December 28, 1944, while a passenger in the defendant's automobile. She had been acquainted with the defendant for twenty-two years. The plaintiff, her husband, and the defendant Phipps were all in the employ of the Portsmouth Navy Yard. Before the accident it was the plaintiff's practice to ride back and forth to work with the defendant. He was accustomed to call at her house, and when the accident o

posture:
ACTION OF CASE, for negligence. The defendant Phipps pleaded in bar the plaintiff's covenant not to sue. By replication, the plaintiff alleged that the covenant was obtained by fraud, mistake, and undue influence, and that she was mentally unfit to transact business when the covenant was executed. Trial by jury, upon the issues raised by the replication. At the close of the evidence, the issues of mistake and fraud were withdrawn from the jury, subject to the plaintiff's exceptions. The jury found that the plaintiff was of sound mind, but that the covenant was obtained by undue influence. To
the denial of his motion for a nonsuit, and of a motion to set aside the verdict, the defendant excepted. In the course of the trial the plaintiff also took certain other exceptions. The Trial Court ordered the covenant set aside, and trial upon the issue of negligence. Further facts appear in the opinion. The exceptions of both parties were reserved and transferred by Leahy, J.
